riddles.text:
In hall of lord, I stand so tall,
With arms of iron, I guard them all.
No flesh have I, yet foes I stay,
In darkened night or bright of day.
What am I?

I am no bird, yet I do soar,
Above the fields where battles roar.
With cloth and thread, my colors fly,
Proclaiming lordship to the sky.
What am I?

I’m born of fire, yet cold I lie,
In peasant’s hand or king’s, I ply.
I reap the field or end a strife,
My edge brings death or sustains life.
What am I?

I travel far, yet never stray,
My master’s words I bear always.
No legs I have, nor feet to roam,
Yet swiftly reach a distant home.
What am I?

In castle’s heart, I glow with might,
I banish shadows, bring warmth to night.
But feed me not, or I’ll consume,
The very hall I once illumed.
What am I?

I’m clad in mail, yet fight I not,
I bear the load where knights cannot.
With steady tread, I bear the load,
Through mud and mire on endless road.
What am I?

My pages turn, yet I’m no mill,
With quill and ink, I hold my will.
In scholar’s hall, I’m born to tell,
Of tales of war or lands that dwell.
What am I?

I’m crowned with thorns, yet rule no land,
My kingdom lies in labor’s hand.
I’m sown in spring, in autumn shorn,
From me, the bread of life is born.
What am I?

I’m strung with care, yet sing no tune,
My flight is swift beneath the moon.
In hunter Paul sent me,
And pierce the heart of foe and friend.
What am I?

I grind the grain to make your bread,
With turning stone, my work is led.
By water’s force or wind’s embrace,
I serve the town in sturdy place.
What am I?

I’m forged in fire, yet wielded cold,
In warrior’s hand, I’m fierce and bold.
My point can pierce through mail and bone,
In battle’s clash, my name is known.
What am I?

I’m made of hide, yet walk I not,
In scholar’s hall, my use is sought.
With ink and quill, I hold the lore,
Of tales and laws from days of yore.
What am I?

I’m bound in chains, yet guard the gate,
My weight ensures the castle’s fate.
Raised or lowered by a wheel’s turn,
I hold the foe or let them burn.
What am I?

I’m filled with feathers, yet fly I none,
On lord’s high bed, my work is done.
Soft and warm, I ease the night,
For weary bones till morning’s light.
What am I?

I’m turned by hand, yet grind no corn,
With wool or flax, my thread is born.
In cottage small, I spin my tale,
For cloth to weave or sail to sail.
What am I?

I’m clad in iron, yet fight no war,
I hold the flame where soups restore.
In kitchen’s heart, I stand with might,
To cook the feast from morn till night.
What am I?

I’m drawn through fields, yet bear no load,
My sharpened edge turns earth’s abode.
With ox or horse, I carve the land,
For crops to grow by farmer’s hand.
What am I?

I’m strung with gut, yet sing no note,
My bolts fly swift from castle’s throat.
In siege or hunt, I claim my prey,
With aim precise, I win the day.
What am I?

I’m built of stone, yet move I do,
With wind or water, I grind true.
In village heart, I crush the grain,
To feed the folk through sun or rain.
What am I?

I’m worn by knights, yet no armor I,
My colors bold catch every eye.
Draped o’er mail, I bear the crest,
Proclaiming lord from east to west.
What am I?

I’m small and round, yet wealth I bring,
In merchant’s purse, my value sings.
Stamped with kings, I trade for bread,
Or buy the steel to keep you fed.
What am I?

I’m long and stout, yet sail I none,
In builder’s hand, my work is done.
I frame the hall or bridge’s span,
To hold the weight of beast and man.
What am I?

I’m sharp and swift, yet cut no wood,
In tailor’s hand, I serve the good.
With thread I dance, through cloth I glide,
To mend the tear or craft with pride.
What am I?

I’m filled with wax, yet burn I not,
In scribe’s dim hall, my use is sought.
I mark the deal or seal the fate,
Of lords and lands in waxen state.
What am I?

I’m yoked to earth, yet roam I free,
With plow or cart, I toil for thee.
My strength pulls loads through mud and mire,
For farmer’s gain or lord’s desire.
What am I?

I’m woven tight, yet worn I’m not,
In sailor’s hand, my strength is sought.
I catch the wind to drive the ship,
Across the seas on trading trip.
What am I?

I’m small and black, yet spark I bring,
In tinder’s bed, my flame will sing.
With flint I strike to light the way,
For warmth or work at end of day.
What am I?

I’m carved with care, yet hold no drink,
In craftsman’s shop, I’m made to link.
With pegs and joints, I form the frame,
Of chair or chest, I bear the name.
What am I?

I’m fed with wood, yet eat I none,
In smithy’s glow, my work is done.
My heat shapes steel for sword or shoe,
With bellows’ breath, my flames grow true.
What am I?

I’m tied to post, yet roam I far,
With bleating voice beneath the star.
My milk and meat feed lord and knave,
My stubborn heart no chain can save.
What am I?

I’m stretched and dried, yet live I not,
In drum or book, my fate is wrought.
From beast I come, with surface tight,
To sound the march or hold the write.
What am I?

I’m swung with force, yet sing no song,
In builder’s hand, I drive along.
With iron head, I strike the nail,
To bind the wood through storm and gale.
What am I?

I’m raised in pens, yet grow no crop,
My bristles coarse, my run won’t stop.
With snout I dig for scraps to eat,
My flesh is prized as tavern meat.
What am I?

I’m turned by key, yet open none,
In tavern’s keep, my work is done.
With twist I pour the ale or wine,
To fill the cup for yours and mine.
What am I?

I’m broad and flat, yet cut no bread,
In mason’s hand, I smooth instead.
With grit and stone, I shape the wall,
To stand through ages, proud and tall.
What am I?

I’m spun with skill, yet wear I none,
In fisherman’s craft, my web is spun.
I trap the fish in river’s flow,
To feed the town when waters grow.
What am I?

I’m hung on wall, yet warm I’m not,
In lord’s great hall, my art is sought.
With threads of gold, I tell the tale,
Of battles won through storm and gale.
What am I?

I’m small and bright, yet light I lack,
In jeweler’s craft, I’m set with knack.
From earth I come, in rings I shine,
A treasure fit for lords divine.
What am I?

I’m pulled by rope, yet sail I none,
In castle’s well, my task is done.
I fetch the water, cold and clear,
For all to drink when thirst is near.
What am I?

I’m clad in fur, yet hunt I not,
In lady’s hand, my warmth is sought.
I shield from cold in winter’s bite,
To keep her hands both soft and light.
What am I?

I’m carved with runes, yet speak no word,
In traveler’s hand, my path is stirred.
I mark the way through wood and vale,
To guide the lost where roads prevail.
What am I?

I’m bound with straps, yet hold no load,
In knight’s strong grip, I’m firmly stowed.
With spurs I prod to urge the steed,
To charge through fields with reckless speed.
What am I?

I’m shaped by flame, yet bear no sword,
In farrier’s craft, my use is stored.
I clad the hoof to guard the way,
For horse to tread through mud and clay.
What am I?

I’m rolled in fields, yet grow no seed,
My weight makes smooth the farmer’s need.
With stones inside, I press the earth,
For crops to thrive and prove their worth.
What am I?

I’m small and sharp, yet build I do,
In carpenter’s hand, my aim is true.
I bite the wood to hold it fast,
For beams to stand while ages last.
What am I?

I’m stretched o’er frame, yet paint I none,
In artist’s craft, my work is done.
With oils and brush, I hold the scene,
Of lords and lands where eyes convene.
What am I?

I’m hauled by beast, yet carry all,
From market goods to castle’s call.
With wheels that creak through rut and stone,
I bear the load till day is done.
What am I?

I’m cast in clay, yet hold no water,
In potter’s kiln, my form is brought.
With glaze I shine for lordly feast,
To serve the meat or brew at least.
What am I?

I’m worn on head, yet no crown I,
In battle’s clash, I shield the eye.
With steel I’m forged to guard the skull,
From foe’s fierce blow or arrow’s pull.
What am I?

I’m ground to dust, yet feed the flame,
In baker’s oven, I earn my name.
With dough I rise to make the bread,
For peasant’s meal or lord’s high spread.
What am I?

I’m bent and strung, yet play no tune,
In hunter’s hand, I strike by moon.
My arrows fly through wood and glade,
To bring the game for feast arrayed.
What am I?

I'm piled with straw, yet sleep I none,
In barn I stand till harvest done.
With pitchfork turned, I feed the beast,
Or pad the stall for winter's feast.
What am I?

I'm shaped by wheel, yet roll I not,
In potter's craft, my form is wrought.
I hold the ale or water clear,
For traveler's thirst when night is near.
What am I?

I'm tied with cord, yet bind no man,
In merchant's stall, my worth is scanned.
With goods inside, I'm slung o'er back,
To carry trade through dusty track.
What am I?

I'm swung in air, yet strike no foe,
In farmer's hand, I lay fields low.
With blade I sweep through stalk and stem,
To reap the harvest, grain by gem.
What am I?

I'm wrought of iron, yet cook no meal,
In stable hung, I aid the heel.
With pointed end, I urge the steed,
To hasten forth with greater speed.
What am I?

I'm laid in rows, yet grow no crop,
In roofer's craft, I reach the top.
With clay or slate, I shield from rain,
To keep the hall both dry and sane.
What am I?

I'm small and round, yet hold no door,
In tailor's hand, I'm used to store.
With thread I'm wound to mend the seam,
Of cloak or tunic, fine or mean.
What am I?

I'm drawn through mud, yet carry none,
In winter's cold, my work is done.
With runners smooth, I glide o'er snow,
To bear the load where wheels won't go.
What am I?

I'm set in earth, yet hold no seed,
In fencer's craft, I meet the need.
With wood or stone, I mark the bound,
To keep the flock or foe not found.
What am I?
